entities.name: Maize
entities.description: Monsoon crop Results of simulation analysis indicate that maize yields in monsoon season are adversely affected due to rise in atmospheric temperatures in all three regions (Fig. 2a).

entities.name: Grain
entities.description: Grain yield decreased with each degree rise in atmospheric temperature.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

The mean baseline yield of rainfed maize crop is about 2 Mg ha⁻¹ in UIGP, where the projected yield loss is up to 7, 11, 15, 22, and 33% relative to baseline yields with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5°C degrees rise in atmospheric temperatures.

entities.name: rainfall

entities.name: temperature
entities.description: However, a 20% increase in rainfall is projected to offset the yield loss due to 1°C rise in temperature.
Similarly, a 30% increase in rainfall is predicted to offset the adverse impact of 2°C rise in temperature.

entities.name: MIGP region
entities.description: In MIGP region, yield reduction of about 8–35% with 1–5°C rise in atmospheric temperature is projected.
In MIGP region, yield reduction of about 8–35% with 1–5°C rise in atmospheric temperature is projected.
In MIGP region, yield reduction of about 8–35% with 1–5°C rise in atmospheric temperature is projected.
In this region, increase in rainfall is likely to offset the temperature rise up to 0.75°C and any increase beyond this temperature will adversely impact the yields, in spite of increase in rainfall.

entities.name: winter
entities.description: Maize crop during winter is provided with assured irrigation and thus yields about 1.5 times more than that of monsoon crop.

entities.name: times more
entities.description: Maize crop during winter is provided with assured irrigation and thus yields about 1.5 times more than that of monsoon crop.

entities.name: temperatures
entities.description: Winter maize grain yield reduced with increase in temperatures in SP and MIGP, but in UIGP rise in temperatures up to 2.7°C is likely to improve the maize yields.
In UIGP, this beneficial effect with rise in temperature is projected to be more up to 2°C rise (13% increase over current yields).
In UIGP, rise in temperatures beyond 2.7°C caused reduction in yield mainly due to reduced number of grains.

entities.name: SP

entities.name: climate change
entities.description: In SP, monsoon season crop is projected to lose grain yield by 21% from current yields due to climate change by 2020 and 35% by 2050 and later.
As far as maize crop grown in winter is concerned, yield gains are projected to be ~5% over current yield in 2020 scenario at UIGP and this benefit is likely to remain till 2050
However, in 2080 scenario, yields are projected to be reduced by 25% from current yields.
The reduction in yield is likely to be to the tune of ~50% by 2050 and about 60% by 2080.
